Richard Armstrong  (1815 – 26 August 1880) was an Irish Liberal politician, and barrister.He was the  son of William Armstrong,  an engineer by profession,  of Roxborough, Co. Armagh, and  his wife Eliza Armstrong (née Steacy).
After graduating in law from Trinity College, Dublin, Armstrong was called to the bar  in 1839 and then, in 1854, became Queen's Counsel.He was considered one of the finest Irish advocates of his time, with numerous courtroom triumphs to  his credit, most notably the Yelverton case.
Armstrong was elected MP as a Liberal candidate for Sligo Borough in the 1865 general election and held the seat until 1868 when he stood down.He was the First Serjeant-at-law of Ireland from 1866 until his death, having previously served as Third Serjeant from 1861 to 1865, and briefly as Second Serjeant in 1865. A very tall man, he was nicknamed "the Big Serjeant" while his  diminutive colleague  Sir Edward Sullivan, 1st Baronet   was "the Little Serjeant".Armstrong married Elizabeth Meurant in 1847, they had at least one son, William Armstrong BL (1848-1899) who married Alice Arundel, and one daughter, Lily (1952-1931) who befriended John Ruskin while she attended Winnington Hall, and was the subject of a watercolour by him, and was a  lily in his  book Lilies and  Sesame: the Ethics of Dust. Lily married Lt. William T. S. Kevill-Davies.
